children.value: Whenever Apollo Server encounters errors while processing a GraphQL operation, its response to the client includes an
array that contains each error that occurred. Each error in the array has an
field that provides additional useful information, including an error
Here's an example error response caused by misspelling the
To help with debugging, Apollo Server defines error subclasses that represent different types of errors that can occur while handling a GraphQL operation (such as
). These subclasses each return a different
, which enables requesting clients to respond differently to different error types.
These built-in error subclasses inherit from the generic
class, and they're all defined in
create your own custom errors and codes
The GraphQL operation string contains a syntax error.
The GraphQL operation is not valid against the server's schema.
The GraphQL operation includes an invalid value for a field argument.
The server failed to authenticate with a required data source, such as a REST API.
The server was unauthorized to access a required data source, such as a REST API.
A client sent the hash of a query string to execute via
, but the query was not in the APQ cache.
A client sent the hash of a query string to execute via
, but the server has disabled APQ.
This is the default error code returned by any
instance that doesn't specify a different code.
Apollo Server throws errors of most built-in types automatically when applicable. For example, it throws a
whenever an incoming operation isn't valid against the server's schema.
Your resolvers can also throw errors in situations where Apollo Server doesn't do so automatically.
For example, this resolver throws a
if the integer value provided for a user's ID is less than
If a resolver throws an error that is
instance, that error is converted to a generic
), along with other relevant error details.
, you can add arbitrary fields to the error's
object to provide additional context to the client. You specify these fields in an object you provide to the error's constructor.
This example builds on the one above by adding the name of the GraphQL argument that was invalid:
This results in a response like the following:
You can create a custom error by defining your own subclass of

import { ApolloError } from 'apollo-server-errors';

throw new ApolloError('My error message', 'MY_ERROR_CODE', myCustomDetailsObject);
error field is useful while developing and debugging your server, but you probably don't want to expose it to clients in production.

You can edit Apollo Server error details before they're passed to a client or reported to Apollo Studio. This enables you to omit sensitive or irrelevant data.
function that is run on each error before it's passed back to the client. You can use this function to mask particular errors, as well as for logging.
modify errors that are sent to Apollo Studio as part of metrics reporting. See
This example returns a more generic error whenever the original error's message begins with
property, which represents the original error thrown in the resolver. You can use this property to obtain the
To make context-specific adjustments to the error received by

You can use Apollo Studio to analyze your server's error rates. If you connect Apollo Server to Studio, all errors are sent to Studio by default. If you

want certain error information to be sent to Studio (either because the error is unimportant or because certain information is confidential), you can modify or redact errors entirely before they're transmitted.
To accomplish this, you can provide a
The usage reporting plugin is installed automatically with its default configuration if you provide an Apollo API key to Apollo Server. To define a custom
function, you need to install the plugin explicitly with a custom configuration, as shown in examples below.
function is called for each error (a
) to be reported to Studio. The error is provided as the function's first argument. The function can either:
Return a modified form of the error (e.g., by changing the
to prevent the error from being reported entirely

This example configuration ensures that any
that's thrown within a resolver is only reported to the client, and never sent to Apollo Studio. All other errors are transmitted to Studio normally.

If it is necessary to change an error prior to reporting it to Apollo Studio (for example, if there is personally identifiable information in the error
Consider an example where the error contains a piece of information like an API key:
throw new ApolloError("The x-api-key:12345 doesn't have sufficient privileges.");
function can ensure that such information is not sent to Apollo Studio and potentially revealed outside its intended scope:
In this case, the error above is reported to Apollo Studio as:
The REDACTED doesn't have sufficient privileges.
